This tells the story so well:
 
I know you well. I knew you from the time I was a black girl in the 5th grade who won the school spelling bee, and the white boy I defeated hid out after school one day to challenge me to a fist fight. (I weighed about 48 lbs...he at least 20lbs more) His dad, a grown white man, asked him how he could have lost to a nigger. What he would have asked him had he lost to any of the other finalists, all of whom were white, several of whom were female, I'll never know.
 
 I knew you when, in Jr. High, a white male teacher told me to my face I was taking the space of a boy, presumably a white one since I went to a predominantly white school, in an advanced math class that required teacher recommendation to get into. And then again in High School when I was a Teacher's Assistant who graded the quantitative portions of tests while the teacher ( a white male who wasn't scared) graded the qualitative portions and when another white male student's father found out, again brought race into the equation accusing me of being incapable of completing this task. Hint...even though I usually knew the answers, I had a legend to go by which my not scared white male teacher eloquently and emphatically made clear to my classmates father and I continued to grade tests.

 Daily Kos: Dear Scared White Men of America
 
 Oversized bullies jumping a smaller girl. Yeah, I am so impressed by these macho macho men...

 
 Well, I'll share a little of my personal history with you. We were very poor growing up. When I was eight, we moved from Columbia, MD on the western shore to the country, a backwoods plot on the Eastern Shore, 15 miles from the nearest place that could be considered even a hamlet. The nearest school to me was called Mt. Vernon School. It had 4 classrooms and served grades Pre-K thru 12. I was the only white boy enrolled in the school that year. I can tell you, being the only one of anything is tough and there are small minded people of all colors, races, and nationalities. Since my time at Mt. Vernon, I've had a wealth of life experiences that have brought me into contact with all walks of life, all 'types' of people, and many nationalities.
 
 I went to college and met the intellectual crowd. While in college I lived in the ghetto (since I paid for everything my self there weren't many other options) and met the people of the ghetto. I've been deeply involved with things that circumvent the law for recreational purposes and have met the people in that circle. I've hitched across the country with very little money and met people from many places in my extensive travels. I've hiked the Appalachian Trail and met tons of people that way.
 
 I've been married to a Muslim woman from Morocco. I'm currently married to a Mexican woman who I met here but went to Mexico to marry.
 
 I can definitively say that NO particular 'type' of person has a monopoly of hate. Having been at least an 'honorary' member of almost every segment of society you could think of, I can tell you that there are great people of every color and race but there is also the WORST of humanity spread throughout the color spectrum. 
 
 As an aside, I'll also tell you that my conservative/libertarian views are formed and informed by these experiences. I've seen that most people know what the 'right' choices are but often ignore them for 'easier' fixes or instant gratification. This has proven true in almost every situation I've found myself in, from banging smack in a flophouse to dealing with owners of ocean front condos. However, the ABILITY to do what is right is there but I've seen that most people will let you do their work for them if you volunteer.

CUNx, what an interesting background.

 CUNx,
 
 My life experiences closely parallel yours, with the exception that my growing up years were in a dying industrial city in the Northeast.
 
 My left/liberal/radical views were formed in the same crucible as yours.
 
 I came away with the firm conviction that the government has the right, duty, and obligation to ensure that no on else's children should have to experience what I did.
CUNx- do you value your experiences growing up, and do you feel that they have been a positive or negative influence on your life?

CUNx, what an interesting background.
 
 When you were a minority, how were you treated?

 
 I'm not sure how you mean. When I was Poor White Trash? When I was living in the ghetto? When I was in Mexico? When I was the only white student in a school that served grades pre-K - 12? I've been treated the gamut just depending on the situation.

CUNx,
 
 My life experiences closely parallel yours, with the exception that my growing up years were in a dying industrial city in the Northeast.
 
 My left/liberal/radical views were formed in the same crucible as yours.
 
 I came away with the firm conviction that the government has the right, duty, and obligation to ensure that no on else's children should have to experience what I did.

 
 I believe in a social safety net, but I've seen people become so hooked on govt. 'help' so as to not be able to function in the real society. I've seen drug addicts figure out ways to make more in a day then I make in a week. I've seen potential and I've seen it squandered. There's a place for govt. but once it takes over the position of provider, people can become like children depending on govt. for everything. I've made so many HUGE mistakes in my life, and will not do those things again because I paid a price for my mistakes. That is how I learned. If you don't pay a price, you won't learn.

CUNx- do you value your experiences growing up, and do you feel that they have been a positive or negative influence on your life?

 
 Oh man, super positive. Who else can feel as comfortable meeting with gang members in a crack house as they are meeting a real estate client? I feel I'm equipped to deal with any situation, anywhere. I've got stories that would blow your socks off. I'm so happy I've packed a lifetime in my first 30 years and I'm as glad for the education I got on the 'street' as the one I got in college.

Interesting. CUNx gives us a personal history, and Chester states that his own personal history closely parallels it. Chester goes on to state:
 
 
I came away with the firm conviction that the government has the right, duty, and obligation to ensure that no on else's children should have to experience what I did. 

 
 While CUNx states: 
 
 
Oh man, super positive. Who else can feel as comfortable meeting with gang members in a crack house as they are meeting a real estate client? I feel I'm equipped to deal with any situation, anywhere. I've got stories that would blow your socks off. I'm so happy I've packed a lifetime in my first 30 years and I'm as glad for the education I got on the 'street' as the one I got in college. 

 
 Proof positive that some view the glass as half empty while others view it as half full. From a sociological standpoint, I found this to be a very interesting contrast.

I've made so many HUGE mistakes in my life, and will not do those things again because I paid a price for my mistakes. That is how I learned. If you don't pay a price, you won't learn.

 
 I too have a simular background to yours CUNx.
 
 And I agree with a lot of what you say.
 
 But I wanted to add,... I grew up in a house with 9 kids and we too were in and out of poverty. (mostly in)
 
 I learned to learn,... from the mistakes of those around me. I didn't have to steal a pack of cigarettes and get caught to learn the consequences of stealing and getting caught. I didn't have to get a girl pregnant at 15 to learn the lifelong problems it creates. etc. I can go on and on.
 
 I just wanted to add that paying a price is not the only way to "learn."

Of course you are correct. There are tons MORE mistakes I could have made but knew better. And most of the mistakes I DID make, I knew better at the time but just 'did my own thing' anyway. My point was that once you DO make a mistake or do something stupid, the quickest way to learn from it (and not repeat it) is to actually pay a price. I wasn't' trying to imply that that's the only way to learn how to behave...sry.
 
 
 As an aside... I'm very surprised a how ordinary that my background has turned out to be. I would have sworn that I'm the only PWT, only white boy, growing up poor, living in the ghetto, heroin shootin, cross country hitching, payin for his own college, marrying Moroccans, Appalachian Trail hiking, guy who ended up in Mexico with a Mexican wife.... I'll admit that I'm a bit miffed to find out that my story is so run of the mill emoticon_cry ...hehe

 And here I thought the book of PWT was little more than my own family's history.
 
 I assure you that you are no more-no less "run of the mill" than a "motherless, raised by teenagers, living in poverty, inner city, public schooled, absent fathered, playing in the alley, bicycle and fort (club house) building (little rascals/ our gang) kind of character that would still be in that scene were it not for the love of electronics and the want to impress a farm girl (met at work- Mc'Donalds) who would later go to college and leave me there,... and marry another then die before I could ever impress her. Living in a "party trailer" and no choice but to join the Marine Corps for a chance to get out of the situations I was in.
 
 Looking back, I knew more people in my situation then than I know in my situation now. Like you I'm as much or more comfortable around "poor white trash folk" than I am around those who "have" and who don't have a background like ours.
...one thing that does make me feel almost one-of-a-kind (in today's society) .... my parents are still married and they both did their best raising me...

 I myself don't think people do, for instance I can be very lazy and instead of thinking next time I will try harder I instead put myself into situations that I find more comfortable. It is possible that this may be an instance of me learning the "wrong" lesson from a situation.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Dear Scared White Men of America...
